...(indistinct) proceeding today with the applications of Messrs Nesamari, Ramushwana, Managa, Ramaligela, Netshivale. Thank you, Mr Chairman, my name is Meyer, initials BH and I'm an advocate at the Pretoria Bar and I've been instructed in this matter by the firm Booyens, Du Preez and Boshoff, represented by my colleague, the attorney, Mr De Klerk.
Thank you very much.  Mr Van Rensburg?

Thank you, Mr Chairman, my name is Van Rensburg, SJ from Kriek and Van Rensburg Attorneys in Tzaneen.  I act on behalf of or under instructions from the State Attorney and I represent the fifth applicant in this hearing.
Thank you, Chairperson.  I'm Lulama Mtanga, David and ...(indistinct) for the Truth Commission.
Mr Van Rensburg, it's your client that has to testify this morning.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, we are indeed prepared and I'd like to call Captain Carlson Netshivale to the stand.
Thank you very much.  Mr Netshivale, do you have any objection to taking the oath?
Thank you, you may be seated.  Thank you, Mr Van Rensburg, you may proceed.
Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Captain, can we start off by you putting your current rank and position on record, please.
Can you tell us something about yourself?  When did you join the police force?
And were you subsequently also a member of the Venda Force?
Evidence has been led so far that you actually were also a member of the Security Branch, is that correct?
When did you join the Security Branch?
I joined the Security Branch immediately after training 1979.
May I interrupt, Mr Van Rensburg?  I seem to be having serious problems with my headphones.  My apologies, could I be assisted?
Is that better now, Judge Khampepe?
Thank you.  Sorry, Mr Van Rensburg, you may carry on.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Mr Netshivale, can you please us something?  How did it come about that you actually joined the Security Branch?  Were you appointed or were you invited or did you make application to join the Security Branch?
After training, I was just selected to join the Security Branch.  I didn't apply for that.
Okay, and was there some kind of security clearance that you had to obtain before you could join the Security Branch?

What I know is that the person doesn't simply join the Security Branch but, there were certain investigations which were made to find out if the person was against or in favour of the government of the day.  But maybe it was found that I was in favour of the government of the day.
Who actually did these investigations that you're referring to?
I can't say who it is because after basic training I was just selected to work in the Security Branch.
As a member of the Security Branch, was it ever expected of you to make such an investigation on other policemen to find out if they were suited to join the Security Branch?

What happened is that for a person to be in the Security Branch, there were enquiries which were made to find out whether the person is for the government of the day or is against the government of the day, just like if a person was in favour of the government, then that person could be taken and work for the Security Branch.
Yes, the question is did you actually investigate some persons for this specific clearance?
Yes, I investigated other people when they were to be appointed to the police service.  There were enquiries so that we can go and investigate that person.
And was it expected of you to file a report on such an investigation?

There were reports which were written and directed to the office and, I think they were filed but personally, I'm not sure if they were filed or not.  But I still remember that everything was written down but I suspect that it was kept for filing.
...(indistinct) If it was found that an applicant was sympathetic to the liberation struggle, do you think he would be appointed to the Security Branch?
You are referring to me or to other people who were employed?
To any person, the question was, Mr Netshivale, would you think that people who were sympathetic towards the liberation struggle would be appointed to the police force?
Let's now turn to the events after 26 October 1981.  That is the day on which the bombing took place at the police station.  What rank ...(intervention)
Pardon, Mr Chairman, yes.  Sibasa police station.  What rank did you hold at the stage?
Were you present at the Sibasa police station on that day?
Can you please start to describe your specific role in the investigation and the interrogation that followed the bombing?
After the bombing of the police station, there were people who were arrested.  And it was then that I was called upon to participate in the interrogation.
Were you every present during the arrest of any of these people?
Did you play any part in their actual arrest at all?
When they were arrested, I was not there.  I saw them while they were in our offices only.
Okay, now, when these people were found yourself in the offices, what were you instructions?  And tell us what was your involvement in that.

What I participated in was when I was instructed to interrogate those people.  And then it was there when I was involved in the assaulting so that they can tell the truth about how the police station was bombed at Sibasa and by whom.

The persons who normally gave instructions were people who were working with those things, more specially, Mr Ramaligela, who is also Mr Managa, they are the people who were seriously involved in this issue.  And others who used to believe in that those people should be beaten up.  And then it was just referred to while we were at work that those people who are against the government must be assaulted.
These people that you have named just now, were they of equal rank to yourself or of higher rank?
They were of higher rank and I was their junior.
Just for the record, Mr Netshivale, Mr Ramaligela and Mr Managa who you've just made reference to, are they applicants number three and four in this application at this hearing?
Do you understand the question, Mr Netshivale?  The question is are you referring to applicants number two and three in this hearing.
Now General Ramushwana testified that at the time, there was an investigation or an interrogation team selected to investigate the bombings.  The question is were you part of that investigation team?
No, I was not part of the investigating team.  I was just called upon to give a little help.
Perhaps we should now turn to more specific instances.  Can you tell this hearing specifically who the persons are who you assaulted or were present when they were assaulted?
Won't you be slow, we are trying to take down what you are saying.  You've indicated that you participated in the assault of Mr Chikororo.
In connection with?  With incidents at Sibasa or any other thing?
Only in connection with the incident after the Sibasa bombing.
Those are the only people I can still remember.
Now starting with Mr Chikororo, can you tell us where did you find him and what did you do to him?

...(indistinct) Mr Chikororo, he was arrested and he was brought to the office which is referred to as 'Vembe' by them.  And there he was interrogated about the bombing of Sibasa police station and he was refusing, saying that he knows nothing, he was beaten and I also participated by using my clubs.
You slapped him with open hands?
Sometimes we used bare hands and because they were not beaten by myself alone, they were also beaten by electric shocks.
And watered bag covering their head.

I think at this moment, Mr Netshivale, we're talking just about Mr Chikororo, you're saying 'they were beaten,' just confine yourself to Mr Chikororo and the question put to you by Mr Van Rensburg is what did you yourself do to Mr Chikororo?  You said you hit him with your open hand, was there anything else you did?  And then perhaps the next question will be asked is 'Did anybody else do something to him in your presence?'  But just at this stage tell us what you personally did to Mr Chikororo.
There is nothing which I did except helping him be beaten.
In what way did you assist?
Did you not at any stage slap him with an open hand?
I've already explained that I slapped him.

Yes, your evidence was a little confusing because it seemed to suggest that what you were explaining, you are also explaining the participation of other people.  Did you use electric shocks on Mr Chikororo?
I can't remember offhand but I know very well that I did slap him.
Well, it happened a long time ago, I can't remember offhand now.  I only remember that I slapped him.
Did you personally participate in assisting anyone to use the water bad method of torture?
I was merely participating in helping or assisting.
Just to hold him so that they shouldn't run away or should not lose whatever had tightened them.
Thank you, Mr Chairperson.  Mr Netshivale, I'm still asking questions about how you assaulted Mr Chikororo only.  Did you assault Mr Chikororo in any way else except to slap him with open hands?
There was no other means that I used in assaulting Mr Chikororo.
If we can now turn to the interrogation of Mr Phosiwa, can you tell us what your part in the interrogation was?
Well, regarding Mr Phosiwa, I did the same as I mentioned earlier?
Only slapping him with open hands?
Yes.  I only slapped him in a similar manner.
Were you ever present when Mr Phosiwa was assaulted by other means, by other persons?
Well, the same methods were used, the bag full of water and electrification method.
Can you tell us in more specifics how he was electrically shocked?

There was equipment which I can really relate to now because I wasn't personally - directly involved in using it.  What used to happen was that they will attach it to the earlobes and it will be put around, sort of like there will be a winding system.  That's all about it, regarding electrification or electric shock.  Well, regarding the water bag, it was about putting a small bag in water, putting it around the head so that he shouldn't breathe well.
Okay, did you ever see the electrodes during the shock treatment being attached to any other part of Mr Phosiwa's body except his ears?
Well, what I can remember, it's only on the earlobes.
And what were you doing whilst the other persons were busy giving him, that is Mr Phosiwa, these electric shocks?  What was your involvement in that?
I was personally involved in helping out, just to hold so that they could not get lose, especially the equipment.
Okay, and what was your personal involvement whilst the wet bag was used on Mr Phosiwa?
Regarding Mr Phosiwa, it was just a similar method, the bag was put around his head and there was a time he will be released, sometimes I was just watching with other  people.
Okay, and during these assaults on Mr Phosiwa and the interrogation whilst you were present, where did you slap him with open hands on his body?
I can just remember that it was on the face and even on the back.
And it happened on only one occasion or several different occasions?
And did it last over a period of days or several occasions on the same day?

It will be an entire period, perhaps even on the following day I wouldn't be in so, I can't tell exactly what happened on the following day however, most of the times I was around, I was on the other office and I will be invited in, especially at the place where they were interrogating.
Are you saying that it is possible that you actually or were present during the assault for several days on Mr Phosiwa?
Yes, I can vaguely remember that it couldn't have been more than two days, I might have seen him for two days.
Is there anything else you want to add to your evidence before this hearing regarding your assault on Mr Phosiwa?
Okay, if we can now turn to the interrogation of the Rev Phoshwana.  Can we start off by asking you what did you personally do to assault the Rev Phoshwana?
In a similar manner, the method was just of holding when the electric shocks were being conducted.
Did you slap the Rev Phoshwana at any stage?
Yes, I did.  I did slap him.
I can just remember that it was just in a similar manner, on the face and on the back.
And were you present when the electric shocks and the wet bag treatment was used on Rev Phoshwana?
Did you do anything more than just holding him so that other persons can give him this treatment?
No.  I didn't do anything beyond that.
This assault by yourself and the other Security Branch policemen on Rev Phoshwana, did it take place over a number of days or only one day?
I can't remember vividly, what I can remember is that it may not have been more than two days.
We come now to the fourth person that you have mentioned and that is Mr Mahumela.  Mr Mahumela was a prosecutor at the time, is that correct?
He's the third person, Mr Van Rensburg.  Isn't he the third person?
Were you present when the said Mr Mahumela was assaulted?
Did you personally assault that said person?
Yes, I did beat him.  I slapped him on the face and on the back.  I also held him down as the electric shock was taking place.
As that bag was put, they will want to resist so I was just holding so that they shouldn't take it off.
Were you present when Mr Mahumela was assaulted by any of the other policemen in any other way than the ways that you've discussed so far?
Yes, I will personally be there at some time but not always.  I might have been out on duty but, during most of the times of his assault, I was there.  He might have been beaten in my absence.

Mr Netshivale, we're not talking about things that happened in your absence, we want to know what you're involvement was.  So the question is did any other policeman in your presence assault Mr Mahumela in any other way than the ways that you have mentioned?
Well, what I can think of is that he was being beaten by other people who were on duty.
And these people, were they members of the Security Branch?
How was he being beaten?  Was he being hit with open hands or fists, was he being kicked, was he being hit with clubs or any other sort of instrument?
I can't remember vividly but he might have been kicked at some stage, he might have been kicked at some stage.  I can't remember so vividly in as far as how the assault took place.
Now you've testified that you were actually only involved in a minor way during these assaults on these four persons, is that correct?
Yes because I will only be invited to come and assist in a similar fashion.
The following people invited me, Mr Managa, Mr Ramaligela and some other senior people whom I cannot recall but these are the people who will invite me.
And as far as you were concerned, what was the object of this torture and interrogation?  Why was it executed on them?

It is because these people were not really in favour of the then government.  And as such they will be arrested because it was assumed that they wanted to contradict the principles of the then government.
So, what are you saying, Mr Netshivale?  Are you saying that they were tortured for the sole reason because they were not in favour of the government?
Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying because ...(intervention)
Were you not trying to get - or was not one of the objectives trying to get them to make some sort of confession or other for the purposes of the police investigation?
One reason was that they should really confess as to who were the people involved in the bombing of the police station.

How do you make a statement as you've just made now, that they were arrested because they were not in favour of the then government if you knew, at that time, that the reason for their arrest was to solicit information with regard to the bombing of Sibasa police station?
Well, the question wasn't put in that fashion.  If it had come that way, I would have answered that they were being beaten so as to bring confession forward.

The question was put to you by your lawyer.  Your lawyer was very specific in questioning you, in trying elicit the reason as to why the persons that you've alluded to as having participated in the assault were assaulted.

I didn't interpret it that way.  I thought the question wanted me to say exactly what I said.  Now that you are putting it that way, I now realise that it had something to do with the confession regarding the police station of Sibasa.
Interesting.  You may proceed, Mr Van Rensburg.
Thank you, Mr Chairperson.  During the time of the assaults and the interrogations on these four persons, were they being asked questions at the same time as the assault?
It wasn't taking place simultaneously.  There was a time when somebody will come in and there will be another person.
I'm sorry, I didn't follow your answer.  Can you just repeat the answer please?
The question was at the time when these people were assaulted, was there certain questions put to them at the same time?
Can you please repeat the question for me?  Are you saying were they being asked personally or are you saying were questions being directed at them at the same time when they were being assaulted?
Yes, the question is were questions being directed at them at the same time during the interrogation and during the assault?
They will be asked questions at the same time as being beaten and on other occasions they will be beaten without being asked questions regarding the person who bombed the police station.
No Sir, the questions were mainly aimed at the identity of the persons who bombed the police station, is that correct?
Yes.  The idea was to find out as to who bombed the police station and where they were.
Now, can you please tell us your personal feelings at the time.  Did you agree with such methods of interrogation?
Personally, at the time, it was necessary for them to be beaten, at the same time being asked as to who bombed the police station.
And why do you say it was necessary for them to be beaten?

Because I used to believe that if they were not beaten, they wouldn't really confess as to who were the people who bombed the police station because at the time, it was a measure event.  No one will just say he or she had bombed the police station if they hadn't done so.

So, I take it from what you've said now that your answer to the question put to you by Mr Van Rensburg which was 'Did you agree with the methods used?' is your answer that you did agree with the methods used?
Well, at the time, there was nothing I could do whether I will agree or not.  I had to follow the course of the day or assault them in a similar fashion.
Okay, would you say that your opinion regarding this and the way that suspects should be interrogated has changed since then?
Could you repeat the question please for me?

Would you say that your attitude - I'll rephrase the question a little bit to make it easier.  Would you say that your attitude as to how suspects should be interrogated, including assault, has changed since 1981?
Because I can now realise that it was terribly wrong and it was not fair for me to have been doing that.
Were you ever alone in the room when you assaulted these four persons that you have testified about?
No, there was no such a time where I was personally and physically alone in the room with them.
Were any of the persons ever seriously injured by yourself during these assaults?
There was no person who was physically seriously injured at the time.
Would you say that any of the persons needed medical attention during or after these sessions with the shock instrument and the wet bag?
Yes, sometimes they were taken for medical attention but, during those days even if they were so assaulted, it was difficult for them to go for medical attention.
We're talking about these particular victims, Mr Chikororo, Phosiwa, Phoshwana, Mahumela?
Were they or were they not taken for medical treatment that you know of?

I can't recall but I don't remember that they were taken to the hospital, in my knowledge.  Maybe they were taken without my knowledge but I don't know anything about that.  They might have gone there but I didn't see that.
I think you still haven't answered the question pertinently.  The question put to you is whether anyone needed any medical attention pursuant to his assault whilst you were present.
Yes.  I think Mr Chikororo was needing medical attention referring to the way he was beaten, he should have taken to the hospital.
Are you referring to the beating by yourself or, what beating specifically?
What I've seen is that he was injured, his mouth was red with blood.
Do you think that any of the persons suffered permanent disability because of this assault in which you had been involved?
Can you perhaps describe the relationship, if any, that you have today with these victims and specifically the four that you've mentioned, that you've assaulted?
I don't have any enmity since it happened.  We used to meet and we greet each other and we share jokes together.  And then to me and them it's over, it was just a thing of the old days.
And do you have anything specifically to tell them today regarding your actions?

To the people I have assaulted, people like Mr Chikororo, Mr Phosiwa, Mr Managa and Mr Mahumela, I feel very sorry that why I did participate in assaulting them.  And then I ask for forgiveness, even to their families, relatives although some of them I have already asked for forgiveness, I'm repeating it today in front of the people to say that I participated - because I participated.  With those words I'm saying forgive me please.  That was for the past, let us now start with new life in the new South Africa.  I thank you.
Is there anything you want to add to your evidence before this hearing?
There is nothing new I want to add.

Thank you, Mr Chairperson, there are no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VAN RENSBURG
Thank you, Mr Van Rensburg.  Mr Meyer, do you have any questions you'd like to ask this applicant, Mr Netshivale?
Just a few questions, Mr Chairman, not many.
Mr Netshivale, you testified in your evidence now that you were invited to assist the other interrogators during the assault, is that correct?
Is it also correct that you, at that stage, you were a constable and you were one of the junior members of the Security Branch?
And is it also correct that the way that things used to be done was that the junior members would participate in the interrogations in general?
The normal practice at that stage was that junior members could participate in the interrogations as they pleased basically.
No, we were normally invited.  We were invited to go and participate.

So, you were not instructed by your senior officers and told by them specifically 'I want you to give this suspect five slaps,' what would happen is that you would be asked to assist during the interrogations, is that correct?
Could you please repeat your question?
The question was, is it correct that you were not instructed to specifically assault a person but you were merely invited to assist in the interrogation?
Then why did you say earlier that you were invited?
Then we were invited, maybe from my office and then I was instructed to assault or to hold.  You were first called and then instructed to do what to do.
Yes, but if you were instructed you were instructed to assist?
Sometimes we were instructed to hold, or we were instructed to assault and then I assaulted.

So Mr Netshivale, are you saying that the only reason why you assaulted those people who you told us you assaulted was because you were instructed to do so?  You never assaulted any of those persons on your volition?
Yes.  Because if it was not allowed, so it was allowed, that is why I was instructed to assault then I assaulted.
So just to get it clear, before you slapped somebody with your open hands, some other person had said to you 'Netshivale, you go to the victim and slap him.'
On the face or on the back or whatever?
That was not referred to, where to assault.
So the only discretion you had was which part of the body to slap the person on?
Yes, that was my own discretion, I was not instructed where to slap.

Mr Meyer, may I interpose, just to get clarity on what he's saying with regard to this particular aspect of his evidence?  Is it your evidence that you were instructed to assault in a particular manner or is it your evidence that you were instructed to assault and it would then be your discretion, you would use your discretion as to how you would assault a particular detainee?  Do you get the difference between the two versions?
Yes, I used my own discretion.
Were you instructed to assault in a particular manner?  Like, for instance, would you be instructed to assault by slapping the suspect?  Would that be your instruction?
There were no instructions on how to assault.
Thank you, Mr Chairman.  So, Mr Netshivale, are you telling us now that you acted solely on the instructions of your senior officers?
But there's a difference in that these things were not happening simultaneously.  I don't know, you are referring to which incidents.
Yes, were you at any stage instructed by Mr Ramaligela to participate in the assault on any of the detainees?
And I take it you told your attorney about that earlier when we started with this hearing?
Could you please repeat your question?
Let me tell it shortly, Mr Netshivale.  It was never put by your attorney, to Mr Ramaligela that you acted on his instructions in the assaults.  How do you explain that?
Maybe he skipped that but, in the statements, it's there.
Yes, I want to put it to you that you also acted on your own, or voluntarily and that it was not only on the instructions of Mr Ramaligela that you assaulted the victims.
There is a certain incidents in which one can just assault without one instructions because it was a tradition that those people must be assaulted but, it started after receiving instructions.
So, you're saying now that there were occasions in which you assaulted the victims yourself without being instructed?

Now with regard to the incidents for which you are seeking amnesty, you're applying for the assault on Mr Chikororo, Mr Phosiwa, Mr Mahumela and Phoshwana.  And I have understood your evidence to mean that with regard to all these incidents, you acted under instructions, specifically from Mr Managa and Mr Ramaligela, to assault these persons.  You have now stated that there would be an occasion where you would assault persons without being instructed.  Would those incidents also relate to the assault on the persons that you have mentioned, the four persons that you have mentioned, Chikororo, Phoshwana, Phosiwa, Mahumela?  Did you at any stage assault any of these persons without any instruction from either Mr Ramaligela or Mr Managa?

That is why I've already explained that the interrogation didn't take place for one day only but, I just - maybe on the other day, maybe I assaulted them without instructions but, I think sometimes, even if they didn't give instructions, because it was known that they were there to be assaulted and interrogated, it could have happened that I assaulted them without such instruction.  But it started with instructions.
Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Mr Netshivale, is it correct that it was normal practice in the Security Branch to use methods of assault and so forth on suspects?

Yes, they were assaulted.  It was not only in the Security Branches.  By then, if a person was arrested, he was supposed to be beaten in order to find out evidence.  In any case people were assaulted.  It wasn't just like today where they are no longer assaulted.
So you did not require any instructions from anyone to assault a suspect?

Sometimes but it was not every person who was to be assaulted but, it depends on how the person is reacting to the questions as they were expected by the interrogator.  If the person is telling the truth, then if he was lying, then he could be beaten or assaulted.
My second question is, there was no need for you to get instructions from any senior officer for you to assault a suspect?

There was a need because, one cannot just assault a person not knowing why he or she was arrested but, if we were told why he's arrested and that he or she be assaulted in connection with that case, it's then that we can do that.

You've just conceded to Mr Meyer's statement that it was normal practice for the Security Police to use methods of assault on suspects and you conceded, you said 'Yes and it was not only restricted to the Security Branch, it was a practise that was prevalent, not necessarily with regard to the Security Branch but also with regard to the other branches of the police.
During those days it was just like that.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.  I have nothing further.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MEYER
Thank you, Mr Meyer.  Ms Mtanga, do you have any questions you'd like to put to Mr Netshivale?
Yes Chairperson, I do have a few.
Mr Netshivale, you have testified that you were present when Mr Chikororo was tortured.  How many people were present at the time you were torturing Mr Chikororo?
I can't remember as to how many there were.  However, there were many.
Can you give us an estimation?
Well, I'm afraid I cannot lie.  I can't tell exactly how many there were.

No, you're not being asked to lie, Mr Netshivale, what Ms Mtanga is asking you is for an estimation.  You said there were many, now that word many is very wide.  What do you call many?  Was it three people, two, twenty people?  Just some sort of idea how many people were present when Mr Chikororo was tortured when you were personally present yourself?
I can estimate that there was more than six.
More than six can mean a thousand.  Are you saying about six people or eight people because more than six means anything above six?

Well, I don't want to say the exact number or the figure which may not have been the right one because I've forgotten, I only know that there were many because I can't really tell you exactly whether there were - or I can only say there were more than six.

Would you say there were about more than six but about in the region of six people?  Because you see more than six means very little, it means only that there were not one, two, three, four or five people or six people.  I mean it can mean there were thousands or hundreds of other people.
Well, there were not one thousand.
No, we're trying to get an estimated figure.  About how many people were there would you say?  I'm not asking you for an exact figure, about how many people?
Well, that's why I said there have been more than six but there were less than ten, I hope.
Now that's a better answer.  Now we've at least go an estimate of the people.
Mr Chikororo will give evidence that there were not less than 15 people who were present at the time he was tortured and who also participated in the torture, what do you say to this?
Well, I can't really deny, I cannot dispute that because you know, there is a proverb which says that the person who was physically tortured or affected cannot forget.

What he wants to know and what he is concerned about in your evidence is that you do not mention the names of the people who participated in the torture besides yourself, Nesamari, Mr Managa and Ramaligela, why is that?
Well, I haven't been asked to specify the other people in terms of names.  I think the question was around the figure.
Can you give us the names of the people who participated with you?
Go ahead and give us the names.
Okay, I thought you wanted to ask.  I can remember Mr Masindi, Mr Morengeni, Mr Mabuda, Mr Thovhakale, maybe somebody will spell it nicely.  Thovhakale, John Managa.
Sorry, can you just repeat that name, I didn't get it.
Is Johan Managa the brother of Mr Managa, the applicant in this matter?
Are there any other names you can remember?
And other people, well, I've forgotten were also there.
Was Mr Ramaligela amongst the people that tortured Mr Chikororo?  Can you remember if Mr Ramaligela and Mr Managa were present at the time and participated in the torture?

Are you specifically referring to Mr Chikororo or to other people?  I can't remember exactly regarding Mr Chikororo, it happened a long time ago.  I can only remember that a specific person was present when it took place.
Can you remember whether Mr Ramaligela and Mr Managa, the applicants at this hearing were present when Mr Chikororo was tortured?
Well, I can vaguely remember regarding Mr Chikororo.
You must say whether you can or can't remember.  Was Mr Managa, your co-applicant and was Mr Ramaligela present when Mr Chikororo was absent when Mr Chikororo was being tortured?
I can still remember that Mr Managa was present.
Did he participate in torturing Mr Chikororo?
Has it not been your evidence that you were instructed specifically by Mr Ramaligela and Mr Managa in assaulting Mr Chikororo?
Could you repeat your question, please?
Has it not been your in your evidence-in-chief that you were specifically instructed by Ramaligela and Managa to assault Mr Chikororo?
